     Weaving Segment Speed, Density, Level of Service, and Capacity
     Weaving segment speed, S (mi/h)                                        37.76

     Capacity of base condition, cb (pc/h)
     Capacity as a 15-minute flow rate, c (veh/h)
     Capacity as a full-hour volume, ch (veh/h)
     Notes
     a. Weaving segments longer than 2500 ft. are treated as isolated merge and diverge areas using the procedures of Chapter 25, "Ramps and Ramp Junctions".
     b. Capacity constrained by basic freeway capacity.
     c. Capacity occurs under constrained operating conditions.
     d. Three-lane Type A segments do not operate well at volume ratios greater than 0.45. Poor operations and some local queuing are expected in such cases.
     e. Four-lane Type A segments do not operate well at volume ratios greater than 0.35. Poor operations and some local queuing are expected in such cases.
     f. Capacity constrained by maximum allowable weaving flow rate: 2,800 pc/h (Type A), 4,000 (Type B), 3,500 (Type C).
     g. Five-lane Type A segments do not operate well at volume ratios greater than 0.20. Poor operations and some local queuing are expected in such cases.
     h. Type B weaving segments do not operate well at volume ratios greater than 0.80. Poor operations and some local queuing are expected in such cases.
     i. Type C weaving segments do not operate well at volume ratios greater than 0.50. Poor operations and some local queuing are expected in such cases.

                                                       FREEWAY WEAVING WORKSHEET
     General Information                                            Site Information
     Analyst                                                                                Freeway/Dir of Travel                     Route 128 NB
     Agency/Company                             VHB, Inc.                                   Weaving Seg Location                      between Route 16 and Grove St.
     Date Performed                             10/15/09                                    Jurisdiction                              MassHighway
     Analysis Time Period                       Weekday Evening Peak Hour                   Analysis Year                             2015 No Build

     Inputs
     Freeway free-flow speed, SFF (mi/h)                            65
                                                                                            Weaving type                                                    A
     Weaving number of lanes, N                                     2
                                                                                            Volume ratio, VR                                                0.39
     Weaving seg length, L (ft)                                     575
                                                                                            Weaving ratio, R                                                0.44
     Terrain                                                        Level
     Conversions to pc/h Under Base Conditions
     (pc/h)                   V              PHF            Truck %            RV %               ET               ER               fHV               fp             v
     Vo1                   1225             0.95               2                 0                1.5             1.2            0.990              1.00           1302
     Vo2                     18             0.92               1                 0                1.5             1.2            0.995              1.00            19
     Vw1                    438             0.95               2                 0                1.5             1.2            0.990              1.00           465
     Vw2                    336             0.92               1                 0                1.5             1.2            0.995              1.00           367
     Vw                                                                        832          Vnw                                                                    1321
     V                                                                                                                                                             2153
     Weaving and Non-Weaving Speeds
                                                         Unconstrained                                                             Constrained
                                            Weaving (i = w)         Non-Weaving (i = nw)                            Weaving (i = w)        Non-Weaving ( = nw)
     a (Exhibit 24-6)                          0.15                       0.00
     b (Exhibit 24-6)                          2.20                       4.00
     c (Exhibit 24-6)                          0.97                       1.30
     d (Exhibit 24-6)                          0.80                       0.75
     Weaving intensity factor, Wi              1.67                       0.96
     Weaving and non-weaving
     speeds, Si (mi/h)                             35.63                              43.02
     Number of lanes required for unconstrained operation, Nw                              0.80
     Maximum number of lanes, Nw (max)                                                     1.40
                b If Nw < Nw(max) unconstrained operation
                f
                c
                g
                d
                e                                                                                         c if Nw > Nw (max) constrained operation
                                                                                                          g
                                                                                                          d
                                                                                                          e
                                                                                                          f
     Weaving Segment Speed, Density, Level of Service, and Capacity
     Weaving segment speed, S (mi/h)                                        39.83
     Weaving segment density, D (pc/mi/ln)                                  27.03
     Level of service, LOS                                                  C
     Capacity of base condition, cb (pc/h)
     Capacity as a 15-minute flow rate, c (veh/h)
     Capacity as a full-hour volume, ch (veh/h)
     Notes
     a. Weaving segments longer than 2500 ft. are treated as isolated merge and diverge areas using the procedures of Chapter 25, "Ramps and Ramp Junctions".
     b. Capacity constrained by basic freeway capacity.
     c. Capacity occurs under constrained operating conditions.
     d. Three-lane Type A segments do not operate well at volume ratios greater than 0.45. Poor operations and some local queuing are expected in such cases.
     e. Four-lane Type A segments do not operate well at volume ratios greater than 0.35. Poor operations and some local queuing are expected in such cases.
     f. Capacity constrained by maximum allowable weaving flow rate: 2,800 pc/h (Type A), 4,000 (Type B), 3,500 (Type C).
     g. Five-lane Type A segments do not operate well at volume ratios greater than 0.20. Poor operations and some local queuing are expected in such cases.
     h. Type B weaving segments do not operate well at volume ratios greater than 0.80. Poor operations and some local queuing are expected in such cases.
     i. Type C weaving segments do not operate well at volume ratios greater than 0.50. Poor operations and some local queuing are expected in such cases.

                   g                                                                             c if Nw > Nw (max) constrained operation
                                                                                                 g
                                                                                                 d
                                                                                                 e
                                                                                                 f
        Weaving Segment Speed, Density, Level of Service, and Capacity
        Weaving segment speed, S (mi/h)                                39.90
        Weaving segment density, D (pc/mi/ln)                          35.29
        Level of service, LOS                                          E
        Capacity of base condition, cb (pc/h)
        Capacity as a 15-minute flow rate, c (veh/h)
        Capacity as a full-hour volume, ch (veh/h)
        Notes
        a. Weaving segments longer than 2500 ft. are treated as isolated merge and diverge areas using the procedures of Chapter 25, "Ramps and Ramp
        Junctions".
        b. Capacity constrained by basic freeway capacity.
        c. Capacity occurs under constrained operating conditions.
        d. Three-lane Type A segments do not operate well at volume ratios greater than 0.45. Poor operations and some local queuing are expected in
        such cases.
        e. Four-lane Type A segments do not operate well at volume ratios greater than 0.35. Poor operations and some local queuing are expected in
        such cases.
        f. Capacity constrained by maximum allowable weaving flow rate: 2,800 pc/h (Type A), 4,000 (Type B), 3,500 (Type C).
        g. Five-lane Type A segments do not operate well at volume ratios greater than 0.20. Poor operations and some local queuing are expected in such
        cases.
        h. Type B weaving segments do not operate well at volume ratios greater than 0.80. Poor operations and some local queuing are expected in such
        cases.
        i. Type C weaving segments do not operate well at volume ratios greater than 0.50. Poor operations and some local queuing are expected in such
        cases.

Roundabout Fact Sheet
                                                              Roundabout Fact Sheet 
                      What is a Roundabout?                                                                         Benefits 
A  Roundabout  is  generally  a  circular  shaped  intersection  where               Roundabouts can  be  alternatives  to  traffic  signals  and  stop  signs 
traffic  travels  in  a  counterclockwise  direction  around  a  center              to  control  traffic  at  intersections.  In  many  cases,  they  have 
island.  Vehicles  entering  the  circulating  roadway  must  yield  to              several advantages over signals and stop signs, including: 
vehicles  already  circulating.  Roundabouts  have  specific  design 
                                                                                      Fewer accidents and injury crashes 
elements that require vehicles to approach and proceed through 
the intersection at slow speeds, increasing safety and efficiency.                        o 37 percent reduction for all crashes and 51 percent 
                                                                                            reduction for injury crashes.  
Figure  1  below  shows  all  the  features  that  are  included  in  a 
typical single lane Roundabout.                                                       Increased pedestrian safety.   
                                                                                          o 89 percent reduction for all pedestrian injury crashes. 

                                                                                      Fewer Vehicle to Vehicle and Vehicle to Pedestrian Conflict 
                                                                                       points.  See Figure 3.  
                                                                                     Figure 3




                                                                      
Roundabouts  are  not  rotaries  or  larger  traffic  circles.    Key 
differences include                                                                   Reduced vehicle speeds 
  1. All  roundabouts  force  the  entering  driver  to  alter  the                       o A properly designed roundabout will reduce vehicles 
     vehicle path around a central island. Rotaries/traffic circles                         speeds 10 to 20 mph depending on approach speed. 
     were  designed  by  providing  a  weaving  length  between 
     entry and exit points.                                                           Eliminates "Lost Time" inherent to traffic signals 

  2. Roundabouts  are  typically  much  smaller  than                                 Traffic capacity increases 3050% over traffic signals 
     rotaries/traffic  circles,  varying  in  size  from  70  feet  to  300           Reduced vehicle delay and fuel consumption 
     feet  in  diameter.   Figure  2  below  is  a  picture  of  an  existing 
                                                                                      Improved air quality by reduced idling 
     rotary being converted to a roundabout. 
                                                                                      Reduced electricity usage (by removing existing traffic signal) 
    Figure 2
                                                                                       therefore less cost to the city 

                                                                                      Reduced road noise 

                                                                                      Sustainable, lower maintenance cost than traffic signals 

                                                                                      Aesthetically pleasing improvement, see Figure 4. 
                                                                                         Figure 4


                                                                                  




        When I first heard it was going in, I thought, "That's crazy; that will never work"... Now, traffic keeps moving all of the time, I've 
        changed my mind 180 degrees."   Bellevue, WA 
Conceptual Improvement Plans
          Preferred Alternative
 Modified Preferred Alternative
Alternatives Evaluation
SECTION A- 1

Alternatives Evaluation
                                            Access to the site is a vital element to the success of the proposed redevelopment
                                            project. As described previously, Riverside Station is currently served by a single
                                            full access driveway located along Grove Street approximately 1,000 feet to the east
                                            of the existing Route 128/I-95 Northbound Ramp to Grove Street. As described
                                            previously, the existing roadway system in the vicinity of the proposed development
                                            represents a complex network of interchange ramps, critical weave sections, and
                                            intersections that provide access to and from one of the busiest corridors (Route
                                            128/I-95) in the state of Massachusetts. Careful consideration of maintaining and
                                            enhancing the mobility in this area and accommodating project traffic is essential.

                                            Throughout the development of the master plan for this project and the development
                                            of the Traffic Impact and Access Study (TIAS) the Proponent has participated in
                                            numerous meeting with MassDOT, MBTA, Federal Highway Administration
                                            (FHWA), City of Newton, and local interested residents. Meetings regularly held
                                            with MassDOT have engaged representatives from all levels of the MassDOT
                                            organization from the Secretary of Transportation to technical staff. Much of the
                                            early discussions were considered working sessions where ideas were exchanged
                                            and the general feasibility of alternative improvements were discussed. All parties
                                            that participated in the meetings, as represented above, provided useful suggestions
                                            and ideas, many of which have been vetted through this process. For the purpose of
                                            demonstrating some of the ideas for site access and improvements that have been
                                            considered, this document (Section A-1) has been prepared to present access and
                                            improvement alternatives that have been considered and discussed with MassDOT,
                                            MBTA, City of Newton, and local interested residents.

                                            Throughout the many discussions in the City, there were several themes that we
                                            heard regularly and which inspired a lot of review and consideration. These include
                                            the following:

                                                   Direct Access from Route 128 Northbound to the Site is needed
                                                   Minimizing potential traffic along Grove Street should be a priority
                                                   Improving the Pedestrian Experience along the Corridor is necessary.




\\mawald\ld\10865.00\reports\TIAS\TIAS
Appendix Material\AlternativesDiscussion-   1   Mitigation
FINAL.doc
                                            While there were many other comments and considerations mentioned, these three
                                            things were very consistently the topic of discussion at nearly all the meetings in the
                                            City where the Proponent was a participant. As a result, the Proponent has made
                                            great efforts to ensure that these and other requests are fully considered and
                                            incorporated into the proposed plan to the extent possible. The following provides a
                                            summary of the four primary access alternatives that were developed based on
                                            communication with the City and MassDOT. Graphical exhibits of these four
                                            primary alternatives are also provided. Also included in this section is a brief
                                            summary of other alternatives that were considered early on in the Project
                                            development but which were dismissed by the Proponent, MassDOT, and the City of
                                            Newton because of general infeasibility, potential impacts to area residents and
                                            businesses, and limited benefit to the area.

                                            1.   OPTION A  RIGHT-IN/RIGHT-OUT ACCESS OFF OF FRONTAGE ROAD

                                                 This alternative entails providing right-in/right-out ramps off of the Frontage
                                                 Road that runs parallel to the Route 128 NB Ramp system north of Grove Street.
                                                 Access off of Grove Street would be maintained. Modern roundabouts would be
                                                 installed at the intersections of Grove Street at the Route 128 NB and SB Ramps.
                                                 Refer to the exhibit for Option A.


                                                 Components

                                                    Supplemental right-in/right-out site/MBTA access would be provided by
                                                     way of a new driveway along the east side of the Frontage Road.
                                                    Full site/MBTA access would be provided by way of a new signalized
                                                     driveway along the north side of Grove Street.
                                                    The intersections of Grove Street at the Route 128 NB and SB Ramps would
                                                     be controlled by modern roundabouts.
                                                    Access points between the Route 128 NB Ramps and Frontage Road and
                                                     connections to Recreation Road would be reconfigured to improve
                                                     operations.
                                                    Grove Street Bridge over Route 128 would need to be reconfigured within
                                                     the existing cross section to accommodate four travel lanes.
                                                    Requires a permit to break the no-access line along the Route 128 NB ramps;
                                                    Will require review by the FHWA.


                                                 Evaluation Summary

                                                 As part of this option, landscaped islands would be constructed on Grove Street
                                                 in the areas of the proposed turning lanes, resulting in a similar look and feel to
                                                 the roadway layout at the adjacent Riverside Center office complex, which is a
                                                 layout that is generally viewed positively in the community. Not only does this
                                                 layout contribute to the aesthetics of the corridor, but it also has traffic calming
                                                 properties as well. Further to the south, the proposed roundabouts at the Route
                                                 128 Ramps will also reduce travel speeds along Grove Street and greatly enhance
                                                 safety. These proposed improvements are also tied into a vast on-site pedestrian
                                                 network via a multi-use path that travels along the site frontage, across the Grove




\\mawald\ld\10865.00\reports\TIAS\TIAS
Appendix Material\AlternativesDiscussion-   2    Mitigation
FINAL.doc
                                                 Street bridge over Route 128, and connects with existing sidewalks in the Lower
                                                 Falls area. Crosswalks are provided across the existing Route 128 northbound on
                                                 ramp as well as within the roundabouts at both Route 128 ramp terminals.

                                                 From a traffic volume perspective, the proposed Frontage Road Access Driveway
                                                 alleviates demand at the existing MBTA Site Entrance by providing a more direct
                                                 regional connection. This new access also provides the opportunity to remove
                                                 95% of all bus activity from Grove Street by agreement with the MBTA. In
                                                 addition, modifications proposed for the Frontage Road eliminate existing weave
                                                 movement to Recreation Road and improve existing traffic movements.

                                                 Overall, Option A would result in a Level of Service B or better for the Route 128
                                                 Ramps and MBTA Site Entrance during all peak hours. In addition, Red Sox
                                                 game day traffic and normal commuter traffic will be significantly improved and
                                                 delays will be avoided as a result of state of the art new parking facility.

                                                 While the multiple benefits associated with this are in line with some of the
                                                 themes we heard from the community, there were still some in the community
                                                 who felt this plan did not go far enough to address their concerns. In particular,
                                                 comments were made that the Frontage Road Access Driveway only provided
                                                 limited egress, which would not remove enough traffic from Grove Street. As
                                                 such, the geometric layout at the proposed signalized MBTA driveway was
                                                 viewed as too wide.

                                            2.   OPTION B  RIGHT-IN/FULL EGRESS OFF OF FRONTAGE ROAD
                                                 (CURRENTLY PROPOSED IN THE TIAS)

                                                 This alternative entails providing a right-in/left and right-out driveway off of the
                                                 Frontage Road that runs parallel to the Route 128 NB Ramp system north of
                                                 Grove Street. A two-way connection of the northbound on-ramp between Grove
                                                 Street and the proposed driveway would be constructed. Access off of Grove
                                                 Street would be maintained. Modern roundabouts would be installed at the
                                                 intersections of Grove Street at the Route 128 NB and SB Ramps. Refer to the
                                                 exhibit for Option B


                                                 Components

                                                    Supplemental site/MBTA access would be provided by way of a new
                                                     driveway along the east side of the Frontage Road.
                                                    The Frontage Road, south of the driveway would accommodate two-way
                                                     vehicular travel.
                                                    Vehicles exiting the driveway would have the opportunity to access Route
                                                     128 NB and Grove Street/Route 128 SB.
                                                    Full site/MBTA access would be provided by way of a new signalized
                                                     driveway along the north side of Grove Street.
                                                    The intersections of Grove Street at the Route 128 NB and SB Ramps would
                                                     be controlled by modern roundabouts.
                                                    Access points between the Route 128 NB Ramps and Frontage Road and
                                                     connections to Recreation Road would be reconfigured to improve
                                                     operations.



\\mawald\ld\10865.00\reports\TIAS\TIAS
Appendix Material\AlternativesDiscussion-   3    Mitigation
FINAL.doc
                                            3.   OPTION C  DIRECT ACCESS FROM ROUTE 128 NORTHBOUND
                                                 (MAINTAINING EXISTING NORTHBOUND RAMP FROM GROVE
                                                 STREET)

                                                 This alternative involves the construction of a new ramp that provides direct
                                                 access into the site from Route 128 NB. This ramp would be on the existing high
                                                 speed Exit 23-24-25 ramp. Right-out egress would be provided onto Frontage
                                                 Road. The existing Grove Street/Route 128 northbound ramp would remain in
                                                 operation. Refer to the exhibit for Option C.


                                                 Components

                                                    Supplemental right-in/right-out site/MBTA access would be provided by
                                                     way of a new ramp directly off of the Exit 23-24-25 ramp.
                                                    Full site/MBTA access would be provided by way of a new signalized
                                                     driveway along the north side of Grove Street.
                                                    The intersections of Grove Street at the Route 128 NB and SB Ramps would
                                                     be controlled by modern roundabouts.
                                                    Access points between the Route 128 NB Ramps and Frontage Road and
                                                     connections to Recreation Road would be reconfigured.
                                                    Existing Grove Street/Route 128 northbound ramp would remain in
                                                     operation.
                                                    Grove Street Bridge over Route 128 would need to be reconfigured within
                                                     the existing cross section to accommodate four travel lanes.
                                                    Requires a permit to break the no-access line along the Route 128 NB ramps;
                                                    Will require review by the FHWA.


                                                 Evaluation Summary

                                                 Similar to Options A and B, Option C provides the benefits of landscaped islands
                                                 on Grove Street in the areas of the proposed turning lanes, which contributes to
                                                 the aesthetics of the corridor and has traffic calming properties. Option C would
                                                 also provide similar benefits with the proposed roundabouts at the Route 128
                                                 ramp terminals and the pedestrian amenities on and off site.

                                                 Based on evaluation of existing grades along the Exit 23-24-25 ramp and the
                                                 Frontage Road, maintaining the existing Route 128 Northbound On-Ramp from
                                                 Grove Street is likely infeasible due to the required height of the new bridge that
                                                 would need to be constructed over the Direct Access Ramp to the site. At that
                                                 height, the reconstructed Frontage Road would not be able to descend at an
                                                 acceptable grade without impacting the vertical clearance under the existing
                                                 railroad bridge. This would require the demolition of the existing railroad
                                                 bridge, which some residents in the community have expressed is not desirable,
                                                 as it could potentially be used as a bike trail in the future. Although it has not
                                                 been evaluated, it may be possible to raise the former railroad bridge to improve
                                                 the clearance shortage, but further investigation of alternative constraints suggest
                                                 that this overall plan is very likely not a viable option. Furthermore, based on
                                                 preliminary consultation with FHWA, maintaining the existing Route 128
                                                 Northbound On-Ramp from Grove Street as part of this alternative was deemed



\\mawald\ld\10865.00\reports\TIAS\TIAS
Appendix Material\AlternativesDiscussion-   5    Mitigation
FINAL.doc
                                                   Requires a permit to break the no-access line along the Route 128 NB ramps.
                                                   Will require review by the FHWA.


                                                Evaluation Summary

                                                As part of this option, landscaped islands would be constructed on Grove Street
                                                in the areas of the proposed turning lanes, resulting in a similar look and feel to
                                                the roadway layout at the adjacent Riverside Center office complex, which is a
                                                layout that is generally viewed positively in the community. Not only does this
                                                layout contribute to the aesthetics of the corridor, but it also has traffic calming
                                                properties as well. Further to the south, the proposed roundabouts at the Route
                                                128 Ramps will also reduce travel speeds along Grove Street and greatly enhance
                                                safety. These proposed improvements are also tied into a vast on-site pedestrian
                                                network via a multi-use path that travels along the site frontage, across the Grove
                                                Street bridge over Route 128, and connects with existing sidewalks in the Lower
                                                Falls area. Crosswalks are provided across the existing Route 128 northbound on
                                                ramp as well as within the roundabouts at both Route 128 ramp terminals.

                                                From a traffic volume perspective, the proposed Frontage Road Access Driveway
                                                in Option B alleviates demand at the existing MBTA Site Entrance by provided a
                                                more direct regional connection that allows full access without the need to travel
                                                on Grove Street along the site frontage. Approximately 85% or more of all site
                                                traffic could use the Frontage Road Access Driveway. This new access also
                                                provides the opportunity to remove 100% of all bus activity from Grove Street by
                                                agreement with the MBTA. In addition, modifications proposed for the Frontage
                                                Road eliminate existing weave movement to Recreation Road and improve
                                                existing traffic movements.

                                                Some of the community concerns raised in relation to Option A summarized
                                                above, have been addressed in Option B. In particular, providing full egress
                                                from the Frontage Road Access Driveway removes substantially more traffic
                                                from Grove Street and allows for a reduction in the geometry at the proposed
                                                signalized MBTA driveway. Specifically, one lane can be removed from the
                                                MBTA exit approach and a through lane can be removed on the westbound
                                                approach, which narrows the cross section of Grove Street along the majority of
                                                the site frontage, as compared to Option A. Overall, Option B would result in a
                                                Level of Service B or better for the Route 128 Ramps and MBTA Site Entrance
                                                during all peak hours. In addition, Red Sox game day traffic and normal
                                                commuter traffic will be significantly improved and delays will be avoided as a
                                                result of state of the art new parking facility.

                                                While Option B addresses many of the community concerns, there were still
                                                some in the community that wanted to see a direct access into and out of the site
                                                from Route 128. Initial evaluation of alternatives involving direct access from
                                                Route 128 northbound revealed that there are some significant challenges
                                                associated with implementing a ramp that could operate safely and efficiently
                                                and satisfy design standards and criteria for MassDOT and FHWA. To get a
                                                better understanding of the overall feasibility of direct access, VHB conducted a
                                                more detailed investigation of the topography and the potential horizontal and
                                                vertical alignment of ramps into and out of the site, which is summarized in
                                                Options C and D below.




\\mawald\ld\10865.00\reports\TIAS\TIAS
Appendix Material\AlternativesDiscussion-   4   Mitigation
FINAL.doc
                                                unacceptable. Because FHWA would require the elimination of the existing
                                                Route 128 Northbound On-Ramp from Grove Street, the feasibility of Option C is
                                                even less likely.

                                                From a traffic volume perspective, the Direct Access Ramp in Option C does not
                                                alleviate nearly as much demand at the existing MBTA Site Entrance as Option B.
                                                In fact, the Direct Access Ramp essentially only serves roughly 30% of the site
                                                generated traffic entering the site (versus up to 85% in Option B). This is because
                                                the Direct Access Ramp can only be used by vehicles traveling on Route 128
                                                northbound. All other site generated traffic and MBTA traffic would have to
                                                access the site via Grove Street, which results in 70% of all traffic entering the site
                                                using the existing MBTA driveway. This is in stark contrast to the community's
                                                desire to minimize traffic along Grove Street in this area. Furthermore, in order
                                                to accommodate 70% of the site traffic at the existing MBTA driveway,
                                                significant widening would be required on Grove Street, which far exceeds the
                                                widening proposed under Option B. This, again, is not in line with the
                                                community's concerns.

                                                Based on consultations with MassDOT and a preliminary consultation with
                                                FHWA, there is a strong feeling that in addition to the elimination of the existing
                                                Route 128 Northbound On Ramp from Grove Street, the existing Northbound
                                                Off Ramp from Route 128 to Grove Street would need to be eliminated to have
                                                any chance of justification for the new ramp, due in part to ramp spacing criteria.
                                                FHWA has eight criteria that need to be satisfied in order to justify the need for a
                                                new interstate ramp, the first of which is related to whether or not the existing
                                                ramps can accommodate the existing volume and if they can be modified, in
                                                present form, to accommodate the operational and safety needs. The existing
                                                volumes on the Route 128 Northbound Off Ramp are not high enough to justify
                                                the presence of two ramps, and as such, MassDOT and FHWA have made it clear
                                                that they would require closure of the existing ramp if all other constraints and
                                                design challenges could be met to allow such a project to commence. With the
                                                closure of both the northbound ramps, all Route 128 traffic coming from the
                                                south or heading north would then have to travel through the proposed site to
                                                get on and off Route 128, which would further tax the MBTA driveway, and
                                                place a high volume of at this driveway, nearly a 1,000 feet to the east of the
                                                existing ramp. To accommodate this increase in volume at this location,
                                                substantial improvements, widening would be required, well beyond that
                                                currently proposed in Option B.

                                                From a geometric standpoint, the geometry of the Direct Access Ramp shown in
                                                the Option C exhibit has been described as inadequate by MassDOT and FHWA
                                                because it would be a high speed interstate ramp and minimum design criteria
                                                for decision distance and radii would not be sufficient (as demonstrated in the
                                                Figure). In order to satisfy the design criteria, the ramp would have to depart the
                                                frontage road further north creating more decision distance, and a larger radius
                                                would be required, which ultimately would penetrate much further into the site
                                                and the existing MBTA Rail Yard/Maintenance Facility. Representatives of the
                                                MBTA have stated that such an alignment is unacceptable as there is likely no
                                                way to reconfigure existing operations to accommodate the required change.
                                                Furthermore, even if an acceptable alignment of this ramp could be achieved,
                                                FHWA stated that they would not allow any access points from the ramp into the
                                                site, which ultimately defeats the purpose to the Direct Access Ramp, meaning




\\mawald\ld\10865.00\reports\TIAS\TIAS
Appendix Material\AlternativesDiscussion-   6   Mitigation
FINAL.doc
                                                 that all ramp volume would be sent to Grove Street and then have to access the
                                                 site through another separate access driveway. Based on the feedback received
                                                 from MassDOT, FHWA, and the MBTA on this layout, Option C is not a feasible
                                                 access plan and is not necessary given the benefits associated with, and the
                                                 general feasibility that exists with Option B. In addition, Option C does not
                                                 satisfy the primary concerns of the community and in some areas, it likely
                                                 exacerbates them.

                                                 Many of the constraining features can be summarized as follows:
                                                     Configuration of ramp ingress and egress presented in Option C meets
                                                        minimum design criteria. However MassDOT and FHWA have
                                                        suggested that minimum design criteria would not be approvable so the
                                                        following adjustments would be necessary at a minimum:
                                                             o Increase decision distance between Frontage Road exit from
                                                                 Route 128/I-95 Mainline and new ramp ingress. This would
                                                                 result in substantial impact to the existing MBTA rail facility and
                                                                 may impact wetlands as well.
                                                             o Increase radius for ramp to provide gentle transition and
                                                                 accommodate high speed movement. This would cause
                                                                 substantial impacts to existing MBTA Rail facility and penetrate
                                                                 further east into the site.
                                                             o No access from the Ramp to the site would be allowed, it would
                                                                 connect only to Grove Street. This would defeat the purpose the
                                                                 improvement from the City perspective and require that access
                                                                 to the site be provided from a separate driveway on Grove
                                                                 Street.
                                                     Unlikely that the existing northbound on-ramp from Grove Street to
                                                        Frontage Road could be maintained in its current position due to grade
                                                        challenges.
                                                     Removal of the existing northbound off-ramp to Grove Street would be
                                                        required.
                                                     As a by-product of all of the above, substantial traffic volume increases
                                                        would be expected along Grove Street between the new ramp
                                                        intersection with Grove Street and points west. This is counter to one of
                                                        the main goals of improvement plans being sought.

                                            4.   OPTION D  DIRECT ACCESS FROM ROUTE 128 NORTHBOUND
                                                 (ELIMINATING EXISTING NORTHBOUND RAMP FROM GROVE
                                                 STREET)

                                                 This alternative involves the construction of a new ramp that provides direct
                                                 access into the site from Route 128 NB. This ramp would be on the existing Exit
                                                 23-24-25 ramp. Right-out egress would be provided onto Frontage Road. The
                                                 existing Grove Street/Route 128 northbound ramp would be eliminated. Refer
                                                 to the exhibit for Option D.


                                                 Components

                                                    Supplemental right-in/right-out site/MBTA access would be provided by
                                                     way of a new driveway directly off of the Exit 23-24-25 ramp.




\\mawald\ld\10865.00\reports\TIAS\TIAS
Appendix Material\AlternativesDiscussion-   7    Mitigation
FINAL.doc
                                                   Full site/MBTA access would be provided by way of a new signalized
                                                    driveway along the north side of Grove Street.
                                                   The intersections of Grove Street at the Route 128 NB and SB Ramps would
                                                    be controlled by modern roundabouts.
                                                   Access points between the Route 128 NB Ramps and Frontage Road and
                                                    connections to Recreation Road would be reconfigured.
                                                   Existing Grove Street/Route 128 northbound ramp would be eliminated.
                                                   Grove Street Bridge over Route 128 would need to be reconfigured within
                                                    the existing cross section to accommodate four travel lanes.
                                                   Requires a permit to break the no-access line along the Route 128 NB ramps;
                                                   Will require review by the FHWA.


                                                Evaluation Summary

                                                Similar to Options A and B, Option D provides the benefits of landscaped islands
                                                on Grove Street in the areas of the proposed turning lanes, which contributes to
                                                the aesthetics of the corridor and has traffic calming properties. Option D would
                                                also provide similar benefits with the proposed roundabouts at the Route 128
                                                ramp terminals and the pedestrian amenities on and off site.

                                                However, from a traffic volume perspective, the Direct Access Ramp in Option D
                                                does not alleviate nearly as much demand at the existing MBTA Site Entrance as
                                                Option B. In fact, the Direct Access Ramp essentially only serves roughly 30% of
                                                the site generated traffic entering the site (versus up to 85% in Option B). This is

                                                128 northbound. All other site generated traffic and MBTA traffic would have to

                                                desire to minimize traffic along Grove Street in this area. Furthermore, in order

                                                widening proposed under Option B. This, again, is not in line with the
                                                community's concerns.

                                                closure of both the northbound ramps, all Route 128 traffic coming from the
                                                south or heading north would then have to travel through the proposed site to
                                                get on and off Route 128, which would further tax the MBTA driveway, and
                                                place a high volume of at this driveway, nearly a 1,000 feet to the east of the

FINAL.doc
                                                existing ramp. To accommodate this increase in volume at this location,
                                                substantial improvements, widening would be required.

                                                the Option D exhibit has been described as inadequate by MassDOT and FHWA

\\mawald\ld\10865.00\reports\TIAS\TIAS
Appendix Material\AlternativesDiscussion-   9   Mitigation
FINAL.doc
Other Alternatives Considered

                                            As mentioned at the beginning of this section, a number of alternatives were
                                            examined during the master plan development and dismissed for varying reasons by
                                            the Proponent, MassDOT, and the City of Newton. These alternatives have
                                            substantial infeasibility issues, impact residential and existing businesses, and do not
                                            provide true benefits, and in some cases they do not satisfy many of the community's
                                            concerns that we have since become aware of during this collaborative process.
                                            However, it is important to provide this list of additional improvement ideas that
                                            were considered to demonstrate the level of effort that has been put forth and the
                                            range of options that were examined to arrive at the proposed mitigation program
                                            that is outlined in the TIAS.

                                            HALF CLOVERLEAF INTERCHANGE  ELIMINATE GROVE STREET NB
                                            RAMPS

                                            This alternative involved the construction of a new ramp system that provides access
                                            between Route 128 NB and Grove Street. The existing Grove Street/Route 128 NB
                                            ramp system would be eliminated.

                                            HALF CLOVERLEAF INTERCHANGE  MAINTAIN ROUTE 128 NB OFF-RAMP
                                            TO GROVE STREET

                                            This alternative involved the construction of a new ramp system that provides access
                                            between Route 128 NB and Grove Street. The existing Route 128 NB Off-Ramp to
                                            Grove Street would be maintained.

                                            HALF-CLOVERLEAF INTERCHANGE  CONSOLIDATE ROUTE 16 NB ON-
                                            RAMP

                                            This alternative involved the construction of a new ramp system that provides access
                                            between Route 128 NB and Grove Street. The existing Grove Street/Route 128 NB
                                            ramp system would be eliminated. The existing Route 128 NB On-Ramp from Route
                                            16 WB would be eliminated.

                                            FRONTAGE ROAD ACCESS  ONE-WAY RIGHT-IN/RIGHT-OUT (SIGNAL ON
                                            GROVE STREET)

                                            This alternative involved providing right-in/right-out ramps off of the Frontage
                                            Road that runs parallel to the Route 128 NB Ramp system north of Grove Street.
                                            Access off of Grove Street would be maintained. A traffic signal would be installed
                                            at the intersection of Grove Street at the Route 128 NB and SB Ramps.




\\mawald\ld\10865.00\reports\TIAS\TIAS
Appendix Material\AlternativesDiscussion-   10 Mitigation
FINAL.doc
                                             FRONTAGE ROAD ACCESS  TWO-WAY CONNECTION OF NORTHBOUND
                                             ON-RAMP WITH RIGHT-IN/LEFT AND RIGHT OUT (SIGNAL ON GROVE
                                             STREET)

                                             This alternative involved providing a right-in/left and right-out driveway off of the
                                             Frontage Road that runs parallel to the Route 128 NB Ramp system north of Grove
                                             Street. A two-way connection of the northbound on-ramp between Grove Street and
                                             the proposed driveway would be constructed. Access off of Grove Street would be
                                             maintained. A traffic signal would be installed at the intersection of Grove Street at
                                             the Route 128 NB and SB Ramps.

                                             GROVE STREET ACCESS ONLY  SINGLE SITE DRIVE AT GROVE STREET

                                             This alternative involved providing full access to both the site and the MBTA station
                                             off of Grove Street only (single point of access).

                                             GROVE STREET ACCESS  SITE DRIVE AT GROVE STREET AND
                                             CONSOLIDATE ROUTE 16 NB ON-RAMP

                                             This alternative involved providing full access to both the site and the MBTA station
                                             off of Grove Street. The existing Route 128 NB on-ramp from Route 16 WB would be
                                             eliminated.

                                             NEW ROUTE 128 COLLECTOR-DISTRIBUTOR ROAD

                                             This alternative involved the construction of a new collector-distributor (C-D) road
                                             parallel to Route 128 NB between Route 16 and Recreation Road.



Summary
                                            As part of the development of the proposed mitigation plan, the Proponent has
                                            examined a wide range of access alternatives with varying degrees of feasibility and
                                            desirability. The Proponent has been involved in numerous meetings with the City of
                                            Newton, MassDOT, FHWA, MBTA, and the local community to come up with an
                                            access plan that will operate safely and efficiently and also satisfy the concerns of the
                                            community to the greatest extent possible. The alternatives evaluation summarized in
                                            this section demonstrates the iterative process that has been undertaken. Through this
                                            process and the assessment of each alternative in terms of its ability to provide
                                            efficient site access and address the community's concerns, Option B was chosen as
                                            the preferred alternative as it is the alternative that appears to offer the most
                                            improvement to safety and operations in the area, provide enhanced access to the site,
                                            is generally feasible and can be constructed within the highway layout or on land
                                            under the control of the project Proponent. While all the preliminary work that has
                                            occurred on this project to date has lead to these conclusions, there are still several
                                            formal review processes to navigate to further vet and test these infrastructure
                                            improvements. These include the City of Newton peer review (which will be
                                            undertaken shortly), MEPA, and MassDOT formal design review to name a few. We

                                            expect that as the plan is further developed and the review processes commence, that
                                            modifications to the infrastructure plan, and potentially the project in general, will
                                            occur.
